title: 112_s965
content: The "Family Act of 2011" is the short title of this Act. It includes findings related to families. Congress finds that infertility is recognized as a disease by the World Health Organization and is considered an emerging public health priority by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Approximately 3,000,000 individuals have infertility according to the CDC. Medical insurance coverage for infertility treatments is limited, with only 8 states having laws requiring comprehensive coverage. Medical insurance coverage for infertility treatments is sparse and inconsistent at the State level, with only 8 States having laws requiring comprehensive coverage. Under these State laws, most employer-sponsored plans are exempt, limiting coverage for treatments like in vitro fertilization. According to Mercer's 2005 National Survey of Employer-Sponsored Health Plans, in vitro fertilization was covered by 19 percent of large employer-sponsored health plans and only 11 percent of small employer-sponsored health plans. Medical insurance coverage for infertility treatments is limited, with only 8 States requiring comprehensive coverage. In vitro fertilization is covered by 19 percent of large employer-sponsored health plans and 11 percent of small employer-sponsored health plans, even in States with coverage mandates. Out-of-pocket expenses for these treatments remain significant. SEC. 3. CREDIT FOR CERTAIN INFERTILITY TREATMENTS. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new section providing a credit for infertility treatments. The new section allows eligible individuals a tax credit of 50% of qualified infertility treatment expenses, up to a limit of $13,360 per year. The tax credit for qualified infertility treatment expenses is limited to $13,360 per year for eligible individuals. The credit amount allowable for any taxable year is reduced based on income. The tax credit for infertility treatment expenses is reduced based on adjusted gross income, with a reduction ratio determined by income exceeding $150,000 compared to $40,000. The tax credit for infertility treatment expenses is reduced based on adjusted gross income, with a reduction ratio determined by income exceeding $150,000 compared to $40,000. No credit is allowed if a deduction or credit is taken under another provision. The tax credit for infertility treatment expenses is reduced based on adjusted gross income, with a reduction ratio determined by income exceeding $150,000 compared to $40,000. No credit shall be allowed if a deduction or credit is taken under any other provision, or if reimbursement is received from a Federal, State, or local program. No credit under subsection (a) if reimbursement received from Federal, State, or local program or insurance policy. Insurance reimbursement will not qualify for the tax credit under subsection (a). The credit allowed for any taxable year cannot exceed the regular tax liability plus the tax imposed. The tax credit allowed for a taxable year is limited by the regular tax liability and other credits available, excluding insurance reimbursements. Unused credit can be carried forward to future years. The tax credit allowed for a taxable year is limited by the regular tax liability and other credits available. Unused credit can be carried forward to future years, subject to certain limitations. The tax credit allowable for a taxable year may exceed the limitation imposed by the regular tax liability. Any excess can be carried forward to the following taxable year. The tax credit allowable for a taxable year may exceed the limitation imposed by the regular tax liability and can be carried forward to the following taxable year. If the credit allowable under subsection (a) exceeds the limitation imposed by subsection (b)(4) for the taxable year, the excess can be carried forward to the next taxable year. However, no credit can be carried forward beyond the 5th taxable year after the credit arose, and credits are used on a first-in first-out basis. The credit allowable under subsection (a) can be carried forward to the next taxable year if it exceeds the limitation imposed by subsection (b)(4). However, credits cannot be carried forward beyond the 5th taxable year after the credit arose, and are used on a first-in first-out basis. Qualified infertility treatment expenses refer to amounts paid for in vitro fertilization treatment provided by a licensed medical practitioner. Qualified infertility treatment expenses cover in vitro fertilization administered by a licensed medical practitioner for infertility diagnosed by a U.S. licensed physician. Qualified infertility treatment expenses cover in vitro fertilization administered by a licensed medical practitioner for infertility diagnosed by a U.S. licensed physician. Expenses for fertility preservation procedures conducted before medical treatments that may cause involuntary infertility are also considered qualified infertility treatment expenses. Fertility preservation procedures conducted before medical treatments that may cause involuntary infertility are considered qualified infertility treatment expenses, regardless of subsequent infertility diagnosis. However, expenses for fertility preservation procedures in advance of procedures resulting in infertility or sterilization are not considered qualified infertility treatment expenses. Expenses for fertility preservation procedures conducted before medical treatments that may cause infertility are considered qualified infertility treatment expenses, regardless of subsequent diagnosis. However, expenses for fertility preservation procedures before procedures resulting in infertility or sterilization are not considered qualified infertility treatment expenses. The term 'infertility' refers to the inability to conceive or carry a pregnancy to live birth, including infertility caused by medical treatments. An 'eligible individual' is someone diagnosed with infertility by a licensed physician in the United States. The section defines an "eligible individual" as someone diagnosed with infertility by a licensed physician in the United States. Married taxpayers must file joint returns, and adjustments for inflation apply. The United States has determined filing requirements for married taxpayers to file joint returns. Adjustments for inflation apply to dollar limitations for taxable years after December 31, 2012. After December 31, 2012, the dollar amount in subsection (b)(1) will increase based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year, rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. There is also an income limitation for taxable years. The dollar amount in subsection (b)(2)(A)(i) will increase for taxable years after December 31, 2002, based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year, rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. Beginning after December 31, 2002, the dollar amount in subsection (b)(2)(A)(i) will be increased by a cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year, rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. The taxable year begins in calendar year 2001 instead of 1992, with any non-multiple of $10 amount rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. Conforming amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Section 23A allows for a credit for certain infertility treatments. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to include references to section 23A. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to include references to sections 23A, 25D, and 27.
